item.title: Functions and Graphs
item.description: What is a Function? A function maps each input to exactly one output. We write this as $f(x)$. Linear Functions A linear function has the form: $$f(x) = mx + c$$ Where $m$ is the gradient and $c$ is the y-intercept. Quadratic Functions A quadratic function has the form:

item.title: Quadratic Functions - Introduction
item.description: Lesson Overview Subject Year 11 Mathematical Methods Topic Quadratic Functions Duration 60 minutes Framework VTLM 2.0 / Heathmont Model Learning Intentions By the end of this lesson, students will be able to: Identify the key features of a quadratic function including vertex, axis of symmetry, and x-intercepts Sketch the graph of a quadratic function in the form $f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c$ Interpret the effect of changing parameters $a$, $b$, and $c$ on the shape and position of the parabola Success Criteria Students can demonstrate success by:
